Hafeez recounts his experience of coming
to the West trying to seek asylum in
Afghanistan he worked as a frontline
interpreter for British forces but
following their withdrawal in 2014 he
was left alone facing death threats from
the Taliban desperate to leave he
decided to head for Europe paying
fifteen thousand dollars he was smuggled
to Austria where he was forced to claim
asylum after spending nearly a year in
an immigration center he decided to make
his way to the UK where he was detained
he was there for nearly two months until
being served with the deportation order
the letter did send yeah you guys have
to go and back to Austria and you have a
fingerprint in Austria and your case has
been refused in these countries his case
was refused to enter the Dublin
Convention a piece of EU law allowing
Member States to send asylum seekers
back to the country where they first
lodged their claim for asylum we wrote
to the Home Office but they said they
don't comment on individual cases
Hafeez is not the only person to find
himself in this situation in May this
year a fellow interpreter hanged himself
after being served with the similar
notice others who were still in
Afghanistan described the continued or
dearly suffer when the Sun sets in my
part of the province I get anxious that
someone will attack me because they
already know my name and that I worked
as an interpreter I worry that someone
will come to my house at night
this is Wahid he worked with use forces

he had applied entered the u.s.

these men once seen as vital to the
